242-COE-292 (Introduction to AI) [Common: All Sections / Students] Midterm and Final Exam Score Calculation

Dear Students,
I hope this message finds you well.
Please be informed of the following formulas used to calculate your scaled scores for the midterm and final exams:
Midterm Exam:
Scaled Score = (Your Raw Score Ã— 30) / 33
Final Exam:
Scaled Score = (Your Raw Score Ã— 30) / 31
These calculations are applied to adjust the exam scores to the weightage allocated in the syllabus.
Best regards,
COE-292 Course Coordination Team

242-COE-292 (Introduction to AI) [Common: All Sections / Students] Clarification on COE 292 Final Exam and Help Session

Dear Students,
It has come to our attention that during a help session conducted by an instructor for the COE 292 final exam, some questions from past papersâ€”similar to those in the official examâ€”were discussed.
After a careful and thorough investigation, we have confirmed that while the instructor reviewed over 20 practice questions during the session, only three questions matched those in the final exam.
To ensure fairness and eliminate any potential bias in grading, the three matching questions will be excluded from the final exam score for all students.
Best regards,
COE 292 Course Coordination Team

242-COE-292 (Introduction to AI) [Common: All Sections / Students] Final Update on Assignmnet 2

Dear Students,
Please carefully follow these instructions for Assignment 2:
You must submit a .py file. Do not submit a notebook (.ipynb) file.
You must use the new template available on Blackboard (BB) if not already submitted.
Specific Instructions:
For Task 2:
Hidden layers must use the TH activation function.
The output layer must also use the TH activation function.
Use mse as the loss function.
For Task 3:
Hidden layers must use the relu activation function.
The output layer must use the sigmoid activation function.
Use binary_crossentropy as the loss function.
Please ensure you follow these guidelines carefully.
Best regards,

242-COE-292 (Introduction to AI) [Common: All Sections / Students] Important Announcement for (COE 292 Midterm Exam)

Dear Students,
Weâ€™re excited to share important details about the upcoming COE 292 Midterm exam! Please take a moment to review the following guidelines to ensure a smooth experience.
Date and Location:
Date: Saturday, March 8th, 2025
Time: 09:00 PM to 11:00 PM (2-hour duration)
Location: Building 54
Halls 1-6 for male students
Hall 8~10 for female students
Exam Coverage:
Topics:
Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
Goal Trees and Problem Solving
Machine Learning
Neural Networks (Part 1)
Important Guidelines:
Electronic Devices: Please leave mobile phones, smartwatches, earbuds, and calculators outside the exam hall. These items are not allowed and could lead to disqualification.
ID Requirements: Bring a physical photo ID (preferably your KFUPM ID). If youâ€™ve lost it, request a replacement immediately. Electronic copies will not be accepted.
Arrive Early: Please arrive at least 15 minutes early and check the posted seating arrangements. Remember, you cannot enter after 30 minutes from the start time.
Allowable Exam Materials: Bring an HB pencil, an eraser, and a pencil sharpener. Please do not share or borrow items during the exam.
Breaks: Bathroom breaks are not permitted unless you have an official excuse from Student Affairs.
Exam Format:
The exam will consist of multiple-choice questions (MCQs). You will receive an exam booklet and a Bubble Sheetâ€”please ensure your details are accurate on both. Your name will be preprinted in the bubble sheet, and you will need to write it down in the booklet. Make sure that the version of the bubble sheet and the exam booklet are the same.
At the end of the exam, handover both the bubble sheet and the exam booklet to the assigned instructors. Your grading will be based on the Bubble Sheet only.
Fill in your answers on the Bubble Sheet using a pencil. Only fill one bubble per question to avoid losing points.
If you have special needs, please inform your instructor beforehand.
We believe youâ€™re well-prepared and wish you the best of luck with your studies! If you have any questions, donâ€™t hesitate to reach out to your instructor.
Best wishes,
COE 292 Committee

242-COE-292 (Introduction to AI) [Common: All Sections / Students] Programming Assignment # 1

Dear Students,
Please find the Assignment 1 posted on Blackboard (see Assignments page).
The due date is: 25th Â February 2025, 9:00PM
Submit your solutions on Gradescope following the instructions below.
Please read the assignment instructions carefully:
The assignment is about the KMeans algorithm and its implementation (Topic 3 of the material).
The assignment should be solved individually.
In the Assignments page, you will find Assignment 1 with an attached .zip package that has a notebook (COE292_T242_Assignment1_stu.ipynb).
Use that notebook to solve the assignment.
Read carefully the notebook, description, instructions, pre-written code, hints and comments meant to help you.
Submit your solution as a python file (.py) and not as a notebook. Your submission will not be graded if you submit a notebook (i.e. .ipynb file). Follow the submission instructions in the attached notebook to know how to convert a .ipynb file to .py file. (It is your responsibility to ensure your code executes and passes the autograder tests)
You are encouraged to work on the assignment as soon as you can. Submit your solution on graderscope.com to get feedback about the correctness of your submission from the autograder. You have unlimited number of submissions until the deadline.
Submission is accepted through gradescope only. Any submission not uploaded to gradescope will not be considered.
Code similarity check will be conducted after the deadline. Make sure that any code you submit is your own genuine work.
Additional test cases might be applied after the deadline. Make sure that your code is not tailored only for the test cases of the autograder.
All the best!

The exam is comprehensive
Multiple choice

Around 25% of the questions from the first part (before the midterm exam)
Around 75% of the questions from the second part (after the midterm exam)
Covered material:
Chapter
Topic by Sections
1. Logic
1.1 Propositions and logical operations
1.2 Evaluating compound propositions
1.3 Conditional statements
1.4 Logical equivalence
1.5 Laws of propositional logic
1.6 Predicates and quantifiers
1.7 Quantified statements
1.8 De Morgan's law for quantified statements
1.9 Nested quantifiers
1.10 More nested quantified statements
1.11 Logical reasoning
1.12 Rules of inference with propositions
1.13 Rules of inference with quantifiers
2. Proofs
2.1 Mathematical definitions
2.2 Introduction to proofs
2.3 Best practices and common errors in proofs
2.4 Writing direct proofs
2.5 Proof by contrapositive
2.6 Proof by contradiction
2.7 Proof by cases
3. Sets
3.1 Sets and subsets
3.2 Sets of sets
3.3 Union and intersection
3.4 More set operations
3.5 Set identities
3.6 Cartesian products
Cardinality of Sets
4. Functions
4.1 Definition of functions
4.2 Floor and ceiling functions
4.3 Properties of functions
4.4 The inverse of a function
4.5 Composition of functions
After Midterm Exam
5. Sequences and Summations
5.1 Sequences
5.2 Recurrence relations
5.3 Summations
6. Induction and Recursion
6.1 Mathematical induction
6.2 More inductive proofs
6.3 Strong induction and well-ordering
6.4 Recursive definitions
7. Introduction to Counting
7.1 Sum and product rules
7.2 The bijection rule
7.3 The generalized product rule
7.4 The pigeonhole principle
7.5 Counting permutations
7.6 Counting subsets
7.7 Subset and permutation examples
7.8 Counting by complement
7.9 Assignment problems: Balls in bins
7.10 Binomial coefficients and combinatorial identities
7.11 Inclusion-exclusion principle
7.12 Counting problem examples
8. Discrete Probability
8.1 Probability of an event
8.2 Unions and complements of events
8.3 Conditional probability and independence
8.4 Random variables
8.5 Bernoulli trials and the binomial distribution
9. Advanced Counting
9.1 Solving linear homogeneous recurrence relations
We wish you sucess and excellence.

242-MATH-201-03(Calculus III) Graph r = 1 + 2cos theta

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
# Define the range for theta
theta = np.linspace(0, 2 * np.pi, 1000)
# Define the polar equation
r = 1 + 2 * np.cos(theta)
# Convert to Cartesian coordinates for plotting
x = r * np.cos(theta)
y = r * np.sin(theta)
# Plot the polar curve with axes clearly divided into positive and negative
plt.figure(figsize=(6, 6))
plt.plot(x, y)
plt.axhline(0, color='black', linewidth=0.8, linestyle='--') Â # Horizontal axis
plt.axvline(0, color='black', linewidth=0.8, linestyle='--') Â # Vertical axis
plt.title(r"$r = 1 + 2\cos\theta$")
plt.xlabel("x")
plt.ylabel("y")
plt.axis("equal")
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()
# Plot the polar curve with labeled axes
plt.figure(figsize=(6, 6))
plt.plot(x, y)
plt.axhline(0, color='black', linewidth=0.8, linestyle='--') Â # Horizontal axis
plt.axvline(0, color='black', linewidth=0.8, linestyle='--') Â # Vertical axis
# Add labels for the axes
plt.text(1.1 * max(x), 0, r"$\theta = 0$", fontsize=12, ha='center', va='center') Â # Positive x-axis
plt.text(0, 1.1 * max(y), r"$\theta = \frac{\pi}{2}$", fontsize=12, ha='center', va='center') Â # Positive y-axis
plt.text(-1.1 * max(x), 0, r"$\theta = \pi$", fontsize=12, ha='center', va='center') Â # Negative x-axis
plt.text(0, -1.1 * max(y), r"$\theta = \frac{3\pi}{2}$", fontsize=12, ha='center', va='center') Â # Negative y-axis
plt.title(r"$r = 1 + 2\cos\theta$")
plt.xlabel("x")
plt.ylabel("y")
plt.axis("equal")
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()
